block.p: Dr. Pamela Kendall Stone, the daughter of Gretchen Haug Stone and Judge Lewis B. Stone of New York, was married yesterday to James Joseph Humphrey, a son of the late Frances Carey Humphrey and the late James C. Humphrey. The Rev. Krystin Granberg, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Boathouse in Central Park.

Dr. Stone, 32, is keeping her name. In May, she received a Ph.D. in physical anthropology from the University of Massachusetts. She graduated from Hampshire College in Amherst, Mass., where she is a visiting assistant professor of biological anthropology. In September, she is to begin as the academic coordinator of Hampshire's study program on the Southwestern United States and Mexico. Her father, who retired as a partner in the law firm of Clifford Chance Rogers & Wells in New York, was confirmed last month as a judge in the State Court of Claims in New York. Her mother is the vice president and an owner of the Haug Realty Corporation in New York.

Dr. Pamela Kendall Stone, the daughter of Gretchen Haug Stone and Judge Lewis B. Stone of New York, was married yesterday to James Joseph Humphrey, a son of the late Frances Carey Humphrey and the late James C. Humphrey. The Rev. Krystin Granberg, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Boathouse in Central Park.

Dr. Stone, 32, is keeping her name. In May, she received a Ph.D. in physical anthropology from the University of Massachusetts. She graduated from Hampshire College in Amherst, Mass., where she is a visiting assistant professor of biological anthropology. In September, she is to begin as the academic coordinator of Hampshire's study program on the Southwestern United States and Mexico. Her father, who retired as a partner in the law firm of Clifford Chance Rogers & Wells in New York, was confirmed last month as a judge in the State Court of Claims in New York. Her mother is the vice president and an owner of the Haug Realty Corporation in New York.

Mr. Humphrey, 32, is an equipment operator for Mackin Construction in Greenfield, Mass. His parents worked in Turners Falls, Mass., for the Gill-Montague Regional School District. His mother was a cafeteria manager at the middle school, and his father was an administrative assistant in the district office.
